item.title: OUT NOW! Private Eye issue 1571
item.description: Find out whats in the latest edition of Private Eye. Selected highlights from the UK's number one best-selling news and current affairs magazine including our top stories, cartoons, the Eye crossword, Dumb Britain, Lookalikes, Colemanballs and much more. Plus added extras including our online shop for subscriptions offers, binders and back issues plus the eyePlayer, Covers Library, Blog and Classifieds.

item.title: From In The Back: A backstage drama
item.description: FOUNDED by the great Victorian actor-manager Sir Henry Irving in 1882, the Actors Benevolent Fund (ABF) spends more than ¬£1m a year helping theatre folk experiencing hardship due to injury, illness or old age. The charitys royal patron is Prince Charles, and Dame Penelope Keith has been president since 1990. All very worthy. But behind the scenes theres drama galore.

item.title: From Columnists: What a gasbag!
item.description: THE governments new British energy security strategy carries a foreword written by prime minister Boris Johnson in his unmistakable personal style which begins, characteristically, with an outright falsehood, Old Sparky writes.

item.title: From News: A blind spot on Infosys
item.description: HAVING referred himself to the PMs ethics watchdog, chancellor Rishi Sunak is confident that a review by Lord Geidt will find he declared all his financial interests appropriately. Yet almost everything Sunak has been saying shows the inadequacy of those declarations ‚Ä" notably the omission of his wifes huge financial stake in IT company Infosys.

item.title: From In The Back: Tees with sweeteners
item.description: RATHER than levelling up, the government‚Äôs flagship ‚Äúfreeport‚Äù on Teesside is secretly doing more for the political ambitions of the region‚Äôs mayor and the financial enrichment of a small group of local businessmen.

item.title: From Columnists: Lost in a Russian property maze
item.description: RUSSIA‚Äôs invasion of Ukraine pushed through the new Economic Crime (Transparency and Enforcement) Act, which aims to end the secrecy surrounding UK property ownership, particularly where Moscow gold is involved, writes Slicker. The reassuring government message is that Putin supporters, as well as kleptocrats and drug kingpins, will have ‚Äúnowhere to hide‚Äù their UK assets.

item.title: From News: Praying for Putin
item.description: AMERICAN evangelist Franklin Graham, son of the more famous Billy, had to abandon his 2020 tour of UK cities even before lockdown put paid to it: local councils and arena operators cancelled bookings after discovering that he denounces homosexuals as ‚Äúthe enemy‚Äù and damns Islam as ‚Äúan evil and very wicked religion‚Äù (Eye 1516).

item.title: From Columnists: Keeping the lights (and heating) on
item.description: HOW do we wean ourselves off Russian energy? asks Old Sparky. When the energy price crisis first grabbed public attention in October, we predicted that fracking would reappear on the agenda after the dust from the COP26 conference had settled (Eye 1558). Now it has, with the Mail on Sunday staging a recent head-to-head between industry secretary Kwasi Kwarteng (full steam ahead for cheap green energy) and Nigel Farage (gung-ho for home-produced oil, gas and coal and, yes, shale gas).

item.title: From Street Of Shame: Mary, Mary, quite contrary
item.description: ANOTHER day, another spiral in the wests wholly confected alarm about an imminent Russian invasion of Ukraine, Independent columnist Mary Dejevsky wrote on 21 January. There is no rationale for such a war whatever, and scant evidence that Putin or anyone in or near the Kremlin has anything of the sort in mind.

item.title: From News: In his own words‚Ä¶
item.description: I PASSIONATELY believe in the contribution that the press makes to public life, declared Baron Lebedev of Hampton and Siberia in his first, and so far only, speech to the House of Lords, in May 2021 on the day he was sworn in.
